BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 13, 1916.

PRICE, FIVE CENT

SEC. OF WAR HOPKINS GRADUATE

OUTLOOK AT ANNAPOLIS DARK

HOPKINS SURE TO HEAR SUNDAY

ONLY FIVE MORE DAYS TO GO

Newton D. Baker, Recently Appointed to
Vacant Place in Cabinet by President
Wilson, Received A. B. Degree
From This University in 1892.

Bill to Stop Annual Appropriations to
this University Has Been Reported
Favorably Upon by Committee
and Seems Fated to Pass.

Trustees Grant Y.M.C.A. Use of McCoy
Hall—Date Will Be Set as Soon as
Evangelist's Definite Acceptance Is Received.

News-Letter Sales-Check Competition
Ends this Saturday—Business Staff
Expects Big Results— Prizes
Not Yet Selected.

Newton D. Baker, former Mayor
of Cleveland, who was recently
named Secretary of War by President Wilson, is a graduate of Johns
Hopkins University.
Mr. Baker received his A. B. in
1892, and in 1893 took up postgraduate work at this University.
While an undergraduate he pursued what was then known as
course VI, which dealt exclusively
with history and politics. He continued this course in his graduate
work during the first term of which
he took the following subjects:
Sources of English History and
Historical Jurisprudence, Dr. Emmott; Germanic History and Historical Seminary, Dr. H. B. Adams.
In his second term he resumed
work in the last three courses mentioned above and took, in addition,
American Constitutional Law, Dr.
Schouler ; Money and Banking,
Dr. Sherwood, and Administration,
Prof. Woodrow Wilson. He was
not only a close friend of Mr. Wilson at the time when the latter was
Ills instructor, but has been on intimate terms with the President
ever since.
On President Wilson's recent
tour of the middle West he saw
Mr. Baker in Cleveland and had a
long talk with him. Mr. Baker is
understood to be in thorough accord with the President on his
preparedness program and on his
attitude in regard to questions of
foreign policy.
Mr. Baker is 44 years old. He
was born in Martinsburg, West
Virginia, and at the age of 25 was
appointed private secretary to
Postmaster General Wilson in
President Cleveland's cabinet. In
1897, just four years after leaving
Hopkins, he began to practice law
in Martinsburg. Not long thereafter he moved to Cleveland where
he distinguished himself as a party
leader under Tom L. Johnson'.
Mr. Baker conceived the idea of
home rule for Ohio citizens and
led in the agitation for the new
Ohio constitution, which resulted
in giving to cities the right to frame
their own charters. He led the
efforts which resulted in the new
Cleveland charter, in which preferential voting is one of the most
important features.
For years Mr. Baker has been
known as a leader of the Ohio bar,
and he is highly regarded by the
President as a lawyer. Mr. Wilson
Wanted the vacant cabinet place
filled by a man well versed in law,
because the legal questions con-

The past two weeks have brought
little change for the better in the
situation at Annapolis as regards
Johns Hopkins University. The bill
introduced in the Legislature to stop
the annual appropriation of $50,003
to this University has been reported
favorably upon by the committee
and it is predicted, in all probability,
will be passed as soon as the Prohibition Act, now under consideration, has been finally disposed of in
both Houses.
It has been pointed out to the
Legislature that the money Hopkins
usually receives would be necessary, even if the University were
not to move to Homewood next fall.
Only 20 per cent. of the University's expenses are covered by the
tuition fees, and there is no large
endowment held here, such as exists in other colleges. The University needs funds for its regular
upkeep; even now much of the
equipment for research work, especially in the chemistry department,
is inadequate; and, although it is
not indispensable, the purchase of
some new equipment is considered
highly desirable.
The money given to Hopkins, it
has been shown, would be used almost entirely for the benefit of citizens of Maryland, since 94 per cent.
of the undergraduate _students taking scientific and academic courses
here, and 98 per cent, of the students in engineering, are from this
State.
Dr. Goodnow is in a very peculiar position—as chairman of the
committee to secure economy and
efficiency in disposing of the State's
funds on the one hand and as president of Hopkins on the other. He
must ask for money for the University on the ground that it is
necessary for the great educational
institution of Maryland, and oppose
the giving of it from the standpoint
of economy. Dr. Goodnow has
handled the situation with such tact
and skill that he has won the confidence and applause of the entire
body of delegates at Annapolis. But
whether his appeal before that body
will have the desired effect is regarded at Annapolis as extremely
doubtful.
stantly arising in the administration
of the War Department, the Phillipines, the Panama Canal and
Porto Rico.
Besides being a graduate of
Johns Hopkins, Mr. Baker has received_ degrees from Washington
and Lee University.

It is now practically certain that
Billy Sunday will come to Hopkins.
the trustees of the University have•
granted the Young Men's Christian
Association the use of McCoy Hail
for one day, probably next Monday, at which time the Young Men's
Chr:stian Association may hold any
meet'ng they desire, upon their own
responsibility and under their own
direction.
It only remains to receive Mr.
Sunday's formal acceptance of the
invitation to speak at the University, and no delay is expected from
that source, since it is understood
on very good authority that the
evangelist is anxious for an opportunity to address the Hopkins students.
In order to keep otusiders away,
it is extremely likely that admission to McCoy Hall will be by
ticket only on the day that Mr. Sunday speaks. A definite announcement concerning thi§, however, will
be made by the Young Men's Christian Association within the next
few days.
The occasion is being looked forward to with interest, not only by
Hopkins students, but also by the
general public, which is anxious to
see what form this particular address of the noted evangelist will
take.

POLY WINS PRACTICE MEET

SUMMER SCHOOL OPENS JULY 5

WORK ON'17 HULLABALOO BEGUN

Absence of Important Members of Squad
Causes Hopkins Indeprmdent Swimming Team to Be Defeated
by Score of 30-27.

Range of Courses Offered to Be Larger
Than Ever—Will Include Classes for
Both Candidates for Matriculation and Graduate Students.

White Studio to Be Retained for Photographic Work and Advertising
Again to Be Handled by
Professional.

Handicapped by the absence of
several men, the independent swimming team was defeated in a practice meet last Thursday by the
Polytechnic Institute squad, 30points to 27. Kirk and Nicholson,
Black and Blue representatives in
the relay, too-yard dash and 220yard swim, were prevented from
participating by sickness and examinations. Minus the services of
these men and with a lack of recent practice, the Hopkins men
showed nothing like the form which
has characterized their Nvork earlier
in the season. The Poly boys presented a well-rounded team, but
with all their men in coadition, the
University squad would probably
have experienced but little trouble
ia coming out on top
The first event on the program,
the 200-yard relay, found Poly
winning by two yards. In this
event Hopkins swam only two
regulars, Marshall being detained
in laboratory until too late to participate. Hoffman and Fenniman,
as usual, annexed first for Hopkins
in the fancy diving and plunge for
distance respectively.
In the next event, the too-yard
dash, Rowland swam a beautiful
race, just nosing out Lamdin of
Polytechnic for first. The time for
this event was within two-fifths
of a second of the pool record.
McCormick won another place for
Hopkins by placing first in the 220yard swim, the time being exceptionally fast. Carrigan, of Poly,
sprang a surprise by beating out
Ginsberg in the 50-yard breast
stroke, with Primrose, of Hopkins,
third. The last event, the 50-yard
dash, was marred by poor work on
the part of the starter, who, after
firing his gun twice, let the race
go on. Rowland and Marshall,
thinking the start a false one, were
left half a lap behind before they
were aware that the start had been
allowed. The summary:

The sixth annual 'session of the
summer courses of the University
will begin on Wednesday, ,July 5,
and will continue until. Tuesday,
August 15, inclusive. These courses
'ill be the last classes to be held at
the present site.
The number of attendants at the
summer school has been rapidly increasing since its foundation and a
record number is expected at this
coming session. The plans for the
courses, as drawn up by the director, Dr. Buchner, have not as
yet been formally approved by the
faculty and Board of Trustees, but
it is expected that they will include
all the courses offered in the past,
and probably some additional ones.
Some of ..these courses will be offered to meet the needs of collegi•ate and graduate students who wish
to advance their standing or to
make up deficiencies; others, to enable students, who have not done
so, to matriculate.
For the satisfactory completion
of the work of any course of collegiate grade, a credit of not More
than one-half a regular course will.
be allowed. Likewise, the requirements of one of the two years' work
necessary for the degree of bachelor of arts may be met by attendance and study in three sessions of
the summer school. Students who
have just graduated in June and
who desire to take up graduate
work, may do so immediately at
this coming summer school, and receive credit for it.
The fact that the University, as
a whole, is moving to Homewood
will not interfere in the least with
the summer school, as Such. parts
of the library, apparatus and laboratory equipment necessary will
be kept back until the close of the
cession.

The staff of the 1917 Hullabaloo
is already formulating its plans.
Because of the excellent work done
by the White Studio for this year's
Hullabaloo, the business management has decided to have it take
charge of the photographic work,
for the 1917 Hullabaloo also. Like-,
wise, the policy of putting the advertising in the hands of a professional will be followed next
year, the experience of the present
staff proving that many more advertisements can be obtained by this
means than by the more uncertain
method of indiscriminate commission which has formerly been used.
The staff of the 1917 Hullabaloo
is composed of J. Truernan Thompson, editor-in-chief; C. Prevost
Boyce, business Manager, and Binford, Defandorf, Straus, Stuart,
Baker, Hall, P. Sutton, Weech,
Fulton and Owings, associate editors.
In order to get some money in
its treasury to anticipate some of
the expenses which must be met
'next year, the junior Class will
give a benefit in April at either
the Academy or Ford's. This will,
in part, take the place of the prom
which is generally given by the
juniors, which it has been decided
to omit this year in order not to
cut down the revenue of the class.

Y. M. C. A. Suspends Activities.

All of the activities of the Young.
Men's Christian Association, including the chapel services and the
mission study classes, will be suspended this week on account of the
undergraduate examinations. Next
week, however, Dr. Latane will
lead the chapel services, and the
classes will continue their study of
home and foreign missions. A
prayer group, to meet for five or
ten minutes every day at lunchtime during the Sunday campaign,
is also being organized.

TRIP TO WASHINGTON FOUND
UNNECESSARY BY DEBATERS

The work on the coming triangular debate with the Universities of
Virginia and North Carolina is being carried on uninterruptedly, in
spite of the examinations.
It was thought last week that a
trip to Washington would have to
be made in search of some material
that could not be found in any Baltimore library. The debaters, however, were very pleasantly surprised
to discover the material in a most
unexpected way. What this particular matter contains cannot be
told, but both sides expect to make
good use of it in developing their
debates. The work is progressing
well, and it is safe to say that Hopkins will be represented by two remarkably good teams, each of
which should gain a victory.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, MARCH 13,
MUSICAL CLUBS GIVE CONCERT
AT FOREST PARK HALL

CIRCULATION OF LAYFIELD MEMORIAL PETITION UNDER WAY

The concert of the Musical Clubs
given at the Community Hall, in
Forest Park,_ last Tuesday night
was one of the most successful of
the present season. Both the Glee
and Instrumental Clubs were in fine
form, and the rendition of the entire program was such as to bring
forth enthusiastic and prolonged
applause.
After the concert, the clubs took
part at a dance given in their honor.
Tuesday night was the first time
for several years in which the Hopkins clubs have appeared at this
hall, but the results of the evening
seem to augur that, in the future,
Forest Park will have a regular
place on the clubs' schedule.
There will be no concert given
this week, due to the examinations;
but after next Monday the time of
the clubs is fully occupied. There
will be a concert at the Har Sinai
Temple on March 23, and another
for the quartet and instrumental
sextet at Tonle School on March
25; while, on the thirty-first, the
clubs will travel to Westminster.

The petition for funds for the
erection of the Layfield memorial
is now being circulated about the
University, and is everywhere being liberaly supported.
It is as yet too early to state with
any amount of certainty the figure
which the sum total of the contributions will reach. However, judging from the responses elicited in
one week, enough will be received
to make the memorial in every way
a fitting one.
The committee in charge of the
circulation of the petition has emphasized the fact that there is no
set sum which must be contributed,
and that every individual should donate only what he himself sees fit.

HOPKINS MAN PUBLISHES POEMS
Review of Book of Verse Written by
Aaron Schaffer,'14, Now Graduate
Student at This University.

Few pursuits seem less likely to
be fostered by graduate study in
linguistics than the production of
Poetry. Indeed, no fruits of Johns
Hopkins scholarship is more unexpected than a book of poems. Yet
such a book has recently appeared
"Selected Poems," by Aaron
Schaffer, '14, published by the Poet
Lore Company, of Boston.
Mr. Schaffer's book is a slender
volume of thirty odd lyrics and brief
narrative poems. They are a young
man's poems—some of them distinctly reminiscent of studies as an
undergraduate—all tinged with the
religious fervor of youth and
breathing a high devotion to the
faith and the ideals of Judaism. A
few grow out of reflections on the
war and its horrors.
The author's mood is thoughtful
—often sombre—and the lyrics,
though wholly sincere; lack somewhat the lightness and melody of
songs that must be sung, because
the numbers come. They sometimes, indeed, have a satanic note.
So in "Contrasts," in which he
turns from a Browning lecture,
which people praised without comprehending, to a prize-fight, which
was understood only too well, the
poet is left discouraged and uncertain:
Since 'then I'm in doullt as to which
way is proper,
The way of false gold or the way of
pure copper.

Our resentment of the lassitude
of the first warm day in spring, the
poet blames as follows:
Mankind's a fickle wanton,
Ne'er satisfied nor pleased;
He scolds and fumes at April showers,
Yet by her sun, which loves the flowers,
He cannot be appeased.

The religious sentiment of the
Poems is frank and genuine. Of
the Hebrew tongue, the author
Writes:
It fills me with ambition,
With hope and new born zeal;
The Jewish nation cannot die,
Her gaping wounds must heal!
The Hebrew tongue, the Holy land,
The Jew's religion pure;
The Jewish God, the Jewish home—
Are these not safeguards sure?

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, MARCH 13, 1916.

6

The Medical Standard Book Co.

NEW SYSTEM OF EXAMS BEGINS

PLEADS FOR "LOST MILLION"

307 N. CHARLES ST.

Future Examinations All to Begin on
Monday -First Time for Many Years
Exercises Not Followed
by Recess.

Dr.Beck Recalls Aid Furnished by France
to this Country During Revolution,
and Asks for Help for Sufferers of Present War.

The undergraduate examinations,
which are being held this week,
are the first of a new system, which
from this time forth will be used
entirely at Johns Hopkins University.
For the last several years, it has
been customary for the undergraduate examinations to begin on Friday
and then to continue until the Wednesday or Thursday of the following week. By this system, it was
possible for the students to have
two, or at least one of their examinations out of the way by the weekend, and for that time to be devoted
to the preparation of the subjects
still to come. This entire system
was based on the supposition that
the examinations would be immediately followed by a vacation, either
the Christmas of Easter holidays,
or the summer recess itself.
With the recent determination by
the faculty, however, that, beginning
next year, there were to be but two
sets of examinations,instead of three,
the holiday immediately following
former examinations had to be left
out of consideration, and as the faculty deemed it highly inexpeditious to
decree an extra week of recess after
the midyear examinations, with the
Easter holidays but a month away,
it became a question of arranging
the schedule of examinations so as
to put the students under as little
strain as possible, that the work of
the next term might be taken up
without interruption.
The present examinations occupy
a peculiar position. They are given
under the past system, in which
three examinations a year were held,
and yet, in form, they..are exactly
like those which will be held under
the coming semester plan.
The schedule for. this week has
ben skillfully arranged. Nearly
every undergraduate student has at
least one examination on Monday
and Wednesday, and, at the same
time, nearly every one has Tuesday
free. By this system, it is possible
to prepare for the Monday examinations during the week-end, and
then to use the intervening day in
work upon the remaining subjects.
In most of the larger colleges in
which the semester system prevails,
the undergraduate students have
from one to three weeks' holiday
at examinations. This is not because of any university regulation,
however, but merely because the enrollment of the institution is so
large that it is imperative for the
various examinations to be spread
out over several weeks, so as to
avoid conflict. In this manner, each
group of students is able to take
its particular examinations within
four or five days, and then to have
the rest of the period to itself.

The Hon. James AI . Beck,. who
was Assistant Attorney-General under President McKinley, spoke last
Saturday night in McCoy Hall on
"The Lost Million," being a presentation of the services rendered
this country by France during our
Revolution, and a plea that we aid
the French war sufferers of today.
The meeting was held under the
auspices of the Surgical Dressings
Committee. President Frank J.
Goodnow, of the University, presided and introduced the speaker.
"I feel great diffidence," Mr.
Beck said, "in being called upon
to address a Baltimore audience in
competition with. the greatest of
modern orators — Rev. William
Sunday. I am at a disadvantage
tonight, for after you have imbibed
the fiery rhetoric of Sunday, my
story will seem truly prosaic." Recalling his speech of some months
ago at the Lyric on preparedness,
Mr. Beck reminded his audience
of the remark he made at that time
of the ignorance of most Americans of the finer points of their
country's history. More of our
people, he said, have read "The
French Revolution" of Carlyle than
have read the works of Parkman ;
more have studied Green's History
than have known of the equally
monumental work of McMasters.
It is for this reason that we fail to
realize that "the American Revolution was an act of sublime audacity." One computation has it
that in 1776 only about one-third
of the American people were supporting the war, and that at least
another third were ardent Tories.
At the time there were almost no
manufactories in the Colonies, but
one arms factory and not a single
powder mill. "The war began in
a struggle for powder, and almost
ended in one." The Battle of Lexington grew out of the desire for
ammunition ; because of the lack of
it Bunker Hill was lost, and even
so sagacious a statesman as Dr.
Franklin suggested that the Continental Army might need to use
bows and arrows.
Mr. Beck then made a somewhat
lengthy digression, tracing the
growth of the French courts and
their contests with the monarchy,
and relating how Pierre Caron, the
royal watchmaker, became involved
in the struggle, to the advantage of
democracy in both France and the
United States. It was while in the
toils of the corrupt court, that Caron, better known as Beaumarchais,
published four "Memoires," which
Napoleon said were the beginning
of the French Revolution. At the
same time, the "Barber of Seville"
was written to continue, on the
stage, his attacks against corrupt
government. Still influential at
court, at the outbreak of the Amer-

DR. GRAVE ADDRESSES CITY
CLUB ON HAMAN OYSTER BILL

Dr. Caswell Grave, of the biological department of this University,
who for six years was on the Shell
Fish Commission of the State of
Maryland, addressed the City Club
last Saturday on the benefits which
would be derived from the passage
of the Haman Oyster Bill.
The Frick Bill, Dr. Grave declared, is a ruthless disregard of
social consequences and a complete
surrender to purely pecuniary considerations—the worship of absolute
financial efficiency.
Dr. Grave illustrated how the
production in 1839 of 710,000 bushels was increased by culture in
1884 to i5,000,000 bushels annually,
and since that time, under the present law, had dropped steadily back
until at present the production is
but 4,469,146 bushels. The passage
of the Frick Bill, he declared, would
cost the State annually $8,000,
whereas the bay should be producmg more than $2,00o,000 annually.
"The Haman Bill," he concluded,
"combines the good features of both
the Shepherd Law and the Frick
Bill; and is the ideal towards which
we should strive."
"My poor woman," said the settlement-worker, "what can I do to
relieve your distress?"
"Can you sing, ma'am?"
"Why—er—a little."
"I wish you'd sing some of the
new ragtime songs, ma'am. Me
and my husband ain't been to a
cabaret in two years."—Ex.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, MARCH 13, 1916.

8

COLUMBIA RIFLE CLUB DEFEATED LIBRARY READY FOR REMOVAL
Hopkins Team Makes Higher Score for
Week Than Any Other Club in the
League Members to Get New
Rifles Below Cost Price.

Plans Settled for Transportation of Books
to Homewood—To Be Completed by
Next Fall—Will Probably Be
Fitted With Steel Cases.

The Johns Hopkins Rifle Club
team added another brilliant victory to its record in its match with
Columbia on Saturday, February
26, making the remarkable aggregrate score of 982 against the 977
made by its opponents. In making
this score the Hopkins team shot
higher than any of the other clubs
in the National Rifle Association
for that week, and moreover, defeated a team which has always
stood near the top of the league.
In this match our team showed
its usual steady and consistent
shooting.. J. M. C. Van Hulstyn
and P. R. Wiggins each made a
score of 198; H. A. Rowland shot
197; W. B. Pratt shot 196, and J.
W. Young made 193.
In the match against the field,
which occurred on March 1, the
score of 982 wfts repeated. H. A.
Rowland and W. B. Pratt headed

The announcement was made
last week that each of the members
of the Johns Hopkins University
Rifle Club will be able to obtain a
Krag carbine, which cost the United States Government $20, for
$2.5o, to use in the outdoor practice. The Club offers this as an

All arrangements for the transportation of the library from McCoy Hall to Homewood have been
made. Although sonic of the books
will be moved in the early part of
the spring, the general moving will
not begin until the first of June and
will be completed before the opening of the summer session.
All the books that are needed for
the work in the summer school,
which is to be held in McCoy Hall,
will be placed in the reading-room
after the others have been removed,
and left there for the use of the
students until the session is over.
Then they also will be placed in the
library in the new Academic Building.
The question of shelving the
books at Homewood has not been
definitely settled, but eventually the
new library will bz entirely fitted
out w:th steel cases. The books
belonging to the biological laboratory will be placed in the basement
of the Academic Building in such
cases next year, while the geological and chemical libraries will be
temporar.ly installed in the big cases
which now stand in the present
reading-room. The shelving in the
reading-room is to be placed in the
offices of the members of the
faculty.
The general plan of the removal
of the library is for boxes just as
long as the shelves in the present
reading-room to be constructed,
and for the entire shelves of books
to be conveyed to Homewood intact. This will avoid all confusion,
and will be a great help in replacing the books on the shelves in the
new library.

will obey the Constitution of the
United States and the great State
of Indiana, and perform the duties
of your office, so help you God?"
The pair nodded assent and the
justice continued: "Then by the
power invested in me by the strong
arm of the law I pronounce you
man and wife, now, henceforth, and
forever, and you will stand committed until the fines and costs are
paid, and may the Lord have mercy
on your souls."—Ex.

Another Favors Recognition.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LErrER:

Dear Sir—The more winning
teams Hopkins can produce, the
higher will be her standing in the
intercollegiate world.
The independent swimming team
has made an enviable record for
itself without the help of the Athletic Association and with no rewards, in the form of letters, awaiting it. If the team were only
recognized and an "H. A. A." or
an "H. S." were awarded to each
member, the swimmers' ranks
would be greatly increased, and
Hopkins, through a still more successful team than the Independents, would mount higher on the
athletic ladder.
In the spring Hopkins supports
a lacrosse, a baseball, a track and
a tennis team. In the winter only
track. Surely we could advantageously add swimming as another
winter sport. Even if the followers of basket-ball get this game
recognized as a winter sport, it
would still mean that the University
would be represented by far fewer
teams than are on the field in the
springtime.
The majority of Hopkins students favor the recognition of the
swimming team, and there seems
to be no valid reason for going
contrary to their wishes. Recognition should be awarded within
the year.

The series of interclass basketball games is now at an end. The
fight for first place has been a
hotly-contested one. The freshman
team showed decided improvement
as the series progressed, but the
juniors displayed real championship form from the very start, with
the exception of one game with the
sophomores. The sophomores did
not have a good start, and, although
they defeated the juniors in one
game, they were not able to stand
the pace. The seniors shared the
same misfortune. The victorious
junior team will receive some sort
of a trophy and the individual players who participated in most of the
games will also receive medals.
These interclass games have
aroused a great deal of interest
among the student body, and every
contest has been attended by a
large crowd. It would seem,
from these indications, that basketball at Hopkins has a fair chance
of beconiing a recognized sport. A
strong team could be chosen from
among the league teams and there
are quite a few graduate and medical students who could be counted
upon.
Mr. Theodore E. Kistler, who
has done most of the work in connection with the formation of the
league, is highly in favor of this
plan. He said that he was very
much pleased with the sportsmanlike way in which all the games
were conducted and the enthusiastic
manner in which the student body
turned out to see them. He also
intimated that if the teams should
so desire it, outdoor goals at Homewood would be erected.
"These recent games," he said,
"are the first of their kind that have
ever been played in the Hopkins
gymnasium, and it certainly gives
me a great deal of satisfaction to
see how successful they have been
in every particular." Mr. Kistler
arranged the schedule of the series
and was referee at every game.

Newton D. Baker, former Mayor
of Cleveland, who was recently
named Secretary of War by President Wilson, is a graduate of Johns
Hopkins University.
Mr. Baker received his A. B. in
1892, and in 1893 took up postgraduate work at this University.
While an undergraduate he pursued what was then known as
course VI, which dealt exclusively
with history and politics. He continued this course in his graduate
work during the first term of which
he took the following subjects:
Sources of English History and
Historical Jurisprudence, Dr. Emmott; Germanic History and Historical Seminary, Dr. H. B. Adams.
In his second term he resumed
work in the last three courses mentioned above and took, in addition,
American Constitutional Law, Dr.
Schouler ; Money and Banking,
Dr. Sherwood, and Administration,
Prof. Woodrow Wilson. He was
not only a close friend of Mr. Wilson at the time when the latter was
Ills instructor, but has been on intimate terms with the President
ever since.
On President Wilson's recent
tour of the middle West he saw
Mr. Baker in Cleveland and had a
long talk with him. Mr. Baker is
understood to be in thorough accord with the President on his
preparedness program and on his
attitude in regard to questions of
foreign policy.
Mr. Baker is 44 years old. He
was born in Martinsburg, West
Virginia, and at the age of 25 was
appointed private secretary to
Postmaster General Wilson in
President Cleveland's cabinet. In
1897, just four years after leaving
Hopkins, he began to practice law
in Martinsburg. Not long thereafter he moved to Cleveland where
he distinguished himself as a party
leader under Tom L. Johnson'.
Mr. Baker conceived the idea of
home rule for Ohio citizens and
led in the agitation for the new
Ohio constitution, which resulted
in giving to cities the right to frame
their own charters. He led the
efforts which resulted in the new
Cleveland charter, in which preferential voting is one of the most
important features.
For years Mr. Baker has been
known as a leader of the Ohio bar,
and he is highly regarded by the
President as a lawyer. Mr. Wilson
Wanted the vacant cabinet place
filled by a man well versed in law,
because the legal questions con-

The past two weeks have brought
little change for the better in the
situation at Annapolis as regards
Johns Hopkins University. The bill
introduced in the Legislature to stop
the annual appropriation of $50,003
to this University has been reported
favorably upon by the committee
and it is predicted, in all probability,
will be passed as soon as the Prohibition Act, now under consideration, has been finally disposed of in
both Houses.
It has been pointed out to the
Legislature that the money Hopkins
usually receives would be necessary, even if the University were
not to move to Homewood next fall.
Only 20 per cent. of the University's expenses are covered by the
tuition fees, and there is no large
endowment held here, such as exists in other colleges. The University needs funds for its regular
upkeep; even now much of the
equipment for research work, especially in the chemistry department,
is inadequate; and, although it is
not indispensable, the purchase of
some new equipment is considered
highly desirable.
The money given to Hopkins, it
has been shown, would be used almost entirely for the benefit of citizens of Maryland, since 94 per cent.
of the undergraduate _students taking scientific and academic courses
here, and 98 per cent, of the students in engineering, are from this
State.
Dr. Goodnow is in a very peculiar position—as chairman of the
committee to secure economy and
efficiency in disposing of the State's
funds on the one hand and as president of Hopkins on the other. He
must ask for money for the University on the ground that it is
necessary for the great educational
institution of Maryland, and oppose
the giving of it from the standpoint
of economy. Dr. Goodnow has
handled the situation with such tact
and skill that he has won the confidence and applause of the entire
body of delegates at Annapolis. But
whether his appeal before that body
will have the desired effect is regarded at Annapolis as extremely
doubtful.
stantly arising in the administration
of the War Department, the Phillipines, the Panama Canal and
Porto Rico.

and Lee University.

that source, since it is understood
on very good authority that the
evangelist is anxious for an opportunity to address the Hopkins students.
In order to keep otusiders away,
it is extremely likely that admission to McCoy Hall will be by
ticket only on the day that Mr. Sunday speaks. A definite announcement concerning thi§, however, will
be made by the Young Men's Christian Association within the next

The occasion is being looked forward to with interest, not only by
Hopkins students, but also by the
general public, which is anxious to

POLY WINS PRACTICE MEET

SUMMER SCHOOL OPENS JULY 5

WORK ON'17 HULLABALOO BEGUN

Absence of Important Members of Squad
Causes Hopkins Indeprmdent Swimming Team to Be Defeated
by Score of 30-27.

Range of Courses Offered to Be Larger
Than Ever—Will Include Classes for
Both Candidates for Matriculation and Graduate Students.

White Studio to Be Retained for Photographic Work and Advertising
Again to Be Handled by
Professional.

Handicapped by the absence of
several men, the independent swimming team was defeated in a practice meet last Thursday by the
Polytechnic Institute squad, 30points to 27. Kirk and Nicholson,
Black and Blue representatives in
the relay, too-yard dash and 220yard swim, were prevented from
participating by sickness and examinations. Minus the services of
these men and with a lack of recent practice, the Hopkins men
showed nothing like the form which
has characterized their Nvork earlier
in the season. The Poly boys presented a well-rounded team, but
with all their men in coadition, the
University squad would probably
have experienced but little trouble
ia coming out on top
The first event on the program,
the 200-yard relay, found Poly
winning by two yards. In this
event Hopkins swam only two
regulars, Marshall being detained
in laboratory until too late to participate. Hoffman and Fenniman,
as usual, annexed first for Hopkins
in the fancy diving and plunge for
distance respectively.
In the next event, the too-yard
dash, Rowland swam a beautiful
race, just nosing out Lamdin of
Polytechnic for first. The time for
this event was within two-fifths
of a second of the pool record.
McCormick won another place for
Hopkins by placing first in the 220yard swim, the time being exceptionally fast. Carrigan, of Poly,
sprang a surprise by beating out
Ginsberg in the 50-yard breast
stroke, with Primrose, of Hopkins,
third. The last event, the 50-yard
dash, was marred by poor work on
the part of the starter, who, after
firing his gun twice, let the race
go on. Rowland and Marshall,
thinking the start a false one, were
left half a lap behind before they
were aware that the start had been
allowed. The summary:

The sixth annual 'session of the
summer courses of the University
will begin on Wednesday, ,July 5,
and will continue until. Tuesday,
August 15, inclusive. These courses
'ill be the last classes to be held at
the present site.
The number of attendants at the
summer school has been rapidly increasing since its foundation and a
record number is expected at this
coming session. The plans for the
courses, as drawn up by the director, Dr. Buchner, have not as
yet been formally approved by the
faculty and Board of Trustees, but
it is expected that they will include
all the courses offered in the past,
and probably some additional ones.
Some of ..these courses will be offered to meet the needs of collegi•ate and graduate students who wish
to advance their standing or to
make up deficiencies; others, to enable students, who have not done
so, to matriculate.
For the satisfactory completion
of the work of any course of collegiate grade, a credit of not More
than one-half a regular course will.
be allowed. Likewise, the requirements of one of the two years' work
necessary for the degree of bachelor of arts may be met by attendance and study in three sessions of
the summer school. Students who
have just graduated in June and
who desire to take up graduate
work, may do so immediately at
this coming summer school, and receive credit for it.
The fact that the University, as
a whole, is moving to Homewood
will not interfere in the least with
the summer school, as Such. parts
of the library, apparatus and laboratory equipment necessary will
be kept back until the close of the
cession.

The staff of the 1917 Hullabaloo
is already formulating its plans.
Because of the excellent work done
by the White Studio for this year's
Hullabaloo, the business management has decided to have it take
charge of the photographic work,
for the 1917 Hullabaloo also. Like-,
wise, the policy of putting the advertising in the hands of a professional will be followed next
year, the experience of the present
staff proving that many more advertisements can be obtained by this
means than by the more uncertain
method of indiscriminate commission which has formerly been used.
The staff of the 1917 Hullabaloo
is composed of J. Truernan Thompson, editor-in-chief; C. Prevost
Boyce, business Manager, and Binford, Defandorf, Straus, Stuart,
Baker, Hall, P. Sutton, Weech,
Fulton and Owings, associate editors.
In order to get some money in
its treasury to anticipate some of
the expenses which must be met
'next year, the junior Class will
give a benefit in April at either
the Academy or Ford's. This will,
in part, take the place of the prom
which is generally given by the
juniors, which it has been decided
to omit this year in order not to
cut down the revenue of the class.

Y. M. C. A. Suspends Activities.

All of the activities of the Young.
Men's Christian Association, including the chapel services and the
mission study classes, will be suspended this week on account of the
undergraduate examinations. Next
week, however, Dr. Latane will
lead the chapel services, and the
classes will continue their study of
home and foreign missions. A
prayer group, to meet for five or
ten minutes every day at lunchtime during the Sunday campaign,
is also being organized.

TRIP TO WASHINGTON FOUND
UNNECESSARY BY DEBATERS

The work on the coming triangular debate with the Universities of
Virginia and North Carolina is being carried on uninterruptedly, in
spite of the examinations.
It was thought last week that a
trip to Washington would have to
be made in search of some material
that could not be found in any Baltimore library. The debaters, however, were very pleasantly surprised
to discover the material in a most
unexpected way. What this particular matter contains cannot be
told, but both sides expect to make
good use of it in developing their
debates. The work is progressing
well, and it is safe to say that Hopkins will be represented by two remarkably good teams, each of
which should gain a victory.

you young rascal.

mean by beating me now

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, MARCH 13,
MUSICAL CLUBS GIVE CONCERT
AT FOREST PARK HALL

CIRCULATION OF LAYFIELD MEMORIAL PETITION UNDER WAY

The concert of the Musical Clubs
given at the Community Hall, in
Forest Park,_ last Tuesday night
was one of the most successful of
the present season. Both the Glee
and Instrumental Clubs were in fine
form, and the rendition of the entire program was such as to bring
forth enthusiastic and prolonged
applause.
After the concert, the clubs took
part at a dance given in their honor.
Tuesday night was the first time
for several years in which the Hopkins clubs have appeared at this
hall, but the results of the evening
seem to augur that, in the future,
Forest Park will have a regular
place on the clubs' schedule.
There will be no concert given
this week, due to the examinations;
but after next Monday the time of
the clubs is fully occupied. There
will be a concert at the Har Sinai
Temple on March 23, and another
for the quartet and instrumental
sextet at Tonle School on March
25; while, on the thirty-first, the
clubs will travel to Westminster.

The petition for funds for the
erection of the Layfield memorial
is now being circulated about the
University, and is everywhere being liberaly supported.
It is as yet too early to state with
any amount of certainty the figure
which the sum total of the contributions will reach. However, judging from the responses elicited in
one week, enough will be received
to make the memorial in every way
a fitting one.
The committee in charge of the
circulation of the petition has emphasized the fact that there is no
set sum which must be contributed,
and that every individual should donate only what he himself sees fit.

HOPKINS MAN PUBLISHES POEMS
Review of Book of Verse Written by
Aaron Schaffer,'14, Now Graduate
Student at This University.

Few pursuits seem less likely to
be fostered by graduate study in
linguistics than the production of
Poetry. Indeed, no fruits of Johns
Hopkins scholarship is more unexpected than a book of poems. Yet
such a book has recently appeared
"Selected Poems," by Aaron
Schaffer, '14, published by the Poet
Lore Company, of Boston.
Mr. Schaffer's book is a slender
volume of thirty odd lyrics and brief
narrative poems. They are a young
man's poems—some of them distinctly reminiscent of studies as an
undergraduate—all tinged with the
religious fervor of youth and
breathing a high devotion to the
faith and the ideals of Judaism. A
few grow out of reflections on the
war and its horrors.
The author's mood is thoughtful
—often sombre—and the lyrics,
though wholly sincere; lack somewhat the lightness and melody of
songs that must be sung, because
the numbers come. They sometimes, indeed, have a satanic note.
So in "Contrasts," in which he
turns from a Browning lecture,
which people praised without comprehending, to a prize-fight, which
was understood only too well, the
poet is left discouraged and uncertain:
Since 'then I'm in doullt as to which
way is proper,
The way of false gold or the way of
pure copper.

Our resentment of the lassitude
of the first warm day in spring, the
poet blames as follows:
Mankind's a fickle wanton,
Ne'er satisfied nor pleased;
He scolds and fumes at April showers,
Yet by her sun, which loves the flowers,
He cannot be appeased.

The religious sentiment of the
Poems is frank and genuine. Of
the Hebrew tongue, the author
Writes:
It fills me with ambition,
With hope and new born zeal;
The Jewish nation cannot die,
Her gaping wounds must heal!
The Hebrew tongue, the Holy land,
The Jew's religion pure;
The Jewish God, the Jewish home—
Are these not safeguards sure?

6

The Medical Standard Book Co.

NEW SYSTEM OF EXAMS BEGINS

PLEADS FOR "LOST MILLION"

307 N. CHARLES ST.

Future Examinations All to Begin on
Monday -First Time for Many Years
Exercises Not Followed
by Recess.

Dr.Beck Recalls Aid Furnished by France
to this Country During Revolution,
and Asks for Help for Sufferers of Present War.

The undergraduate examinations,
which are being held this week,
are the first of a new system, which
from this time forth will be used
entirely at Johns Hopkins University.
For the last several years, it has
been customary for the undergraduate examinations to begin on Friday
and then to continue until the Wednesday or Thursday of the following week. By this system, it was
possible for the students to have
two, or at least one of their examinations out of the way by the weekend, and for that time to be devoted
to the preparation of the subjects
still to come. This entire system
was based on the supposition that
the examinations would be immediately followed by a vacation, either
the Christmas of Easter holidays,
or the summer recess itself.
With the recent determination by
the faculty, however, that, beginning
next year, there were to be but two
sets of examinations,instead of three,
the holiday immediately following
former examinations had to be left
out of consideration, and as the faculty deemed it highly inexpeditious to
decree an extra week of recess after
the midyear examinations, with the
Easter holidays but a month away,
it became a question of arranging
the schedule of examinations so as
to put the students under as little
strain as possible, that the work of
the next term might be taken up
without interruption.
The present examinations occupy
a peculiar position. They are given
under the past system, in which
three examinations a year were held,
and yet, in form, they..are exactly
like those which will be held under
the coming semester plan.
The schedule for. this week has
ben skillfully arranged. Nearly
every undergraduate student has at
least one examination on Monday
and Wednesday, and, at the same
time, nearly every one has Tuesday
free. By this system, it is possible
to prepare for the Monday examinations during the week-end, and
then to use the intervening day in
work upon the remaining subjects.
In most of the larger colleges in
which the semester system prevails,
the undergraduate students have
from one to three weeks' holiday
at examinations. This is not because of any university regulation,
however, but merely because the enrollment of the institution is so
large that it is imperative for the
various examinations to be spread
out over several weeks, so as to
avoid conflict. In this manner, each
group of students is able to take
its particular examinations within
four or five days, and then to have
the rest of the period to itself.

The Hon. James AI . Beck,. who
was Assistant Attorney-General under President McKinley, spoke last
Saturday night in McCoy Hall on
"The Lost Million," being a presentation of the services rendered
this country by France during our
Revolution, and a plea that we aid
the French war sufferers of today.
The meeting was held under the
auspices of the Surgical Dressings
Committee. President Frank J.
Goodnow, of the University, presided and introduced the speaker.
"I feel great diffidence," Mr.
Beck said, "in being called upon
to address a Baltimore audience in
competition with. the greatest of
modern orators — Rev. William
Sunday. I am at a disadvantage
tonight, for after you have imbibed
the fiery rhetoric of Sunday, my
story will seem truly prosaic." Recalling his speech of some months
ago at the Lyric on preparedness,
Mr. Beck reminded his audience
of the remark he made at that time
of the ignorance of most Americans of the finer points of their
country's history. More of our
people, he said, have read "The
French Revolution" of Carlyle than
have read the works of Parkman ;
more have studied Green's History
than have known of the equally
monumental work of McMasters.
It is for this reason that we fail to
realize that "the American Revolution was an act of sublime audacity." One computation has it
that in 1776 only about one-third
of the American people were supporting the war, and that at least
another third were ardent Tories.
At the time there were almost no
manufactories in the Colonies, but
one arms factory and not a single
powder mill. "The war began in
a struggle for powder, and almost
ended in one." The Battle of Lexington grew out of the desire for
ammunition ; because of the lack of
it Bunker Hill was lost, and even
so sagacious a statesman as Dr.
Franklin suggested that the Continental Army might need to use
bows and arrows.
Mr. Beck then made a somewhat
lengthy digression, tracing the
growth of the French courts and
their contests with the monarchy,
and relating how Pierre Caron, the
royal watchmaker, became involved
in the struggle, to the advantage of
democracy in both France and the
United States. It was while in the
toils of the corrupt court, that Caron, better known as Beaumarchais,
published four "Memoires," which
Napoleon said were the beginning
of the French Revolution. At the
same time, the "Barber of Seville"
was written to continue, on the
stage, his attacks against corrupt
government. Still influential at
court, at the outbreak of the Amer-

DR. GRAVE ADDRESSES CITY
CLUB ON HAMAN OYSTER BILL

Dr. Caswell Grave, of the biological department of this University,
who for six years was on the Shell
Fish Commission of the State of
Maryland, addressed the City Club
last Saturday on the benefits which
would be derived from the passage
of the Haman Oyster Bill.
The Frick Bill, Dr. Grave declared, is a ruthless disregard of
social consequences and a complete
surrender to purely pecuniary considerations—the worship of absolute
financial efficiency.
Dr. Grave illustrated how the
production in 1839 of 710,000 bushels was increased by culture in
1884 to i5,000,000 bushels annually,
and since that time, under the present law, had dropped steadily back
until at present the production is
but 4,469,146 bushels. The passage
of the Frick Bill, he declared, would
cost the State annually $8,000,
whereas the bay should be producmg more than $2,00o,000 annually.
"The Haman Bill," he concluded,
"combines the good features of both
the Shepherd Law and the Frick
Bill; and is the ideal towards which
we should strive."
"My poor woman," said the settlement-worker, "what can I do to
relieve your distress?"
"Can you sing, ma'am?"
"Why—er—a little."
"I wish you'd sing some of the
new ragtime songs, ma'am. Me
and my husband ain't been to a
cabaret in two years."—Ex.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, MARCH 13, 1916.

8

COLUMBIA RIFLE CLUB DEFEATED LIBRARY READY FOR REMOVAL
Hopkins Team Makes Higher Score for
Week Than Any Other Club in the
League Members to Get New
Rifles Below Cost Price.

Plans Settled for Transportation of Books
to Homewood—To Be Completed by
Next Fall—Will Probably Be
Fitted With Steel Cases.

The Johns Hopkins Rifle Club
team added another brilliant victory to its record in its match with
Columbia on Saturday, February
26, making the remarkable aggregrate score of 982 against the 977
made by its opponents. In making
this score the Hopkins team shot
higher than any of the other clubs
in the National Rifle Association
for that week, and moreover, defeated a team which has always
stood near the top of the league.
In this match our team showed
its usual steady and consistent
shooting.. J. M. C. Van Hulstyn
and P. R. Wiggins each made a
score of 198; H. A. Rowland shot
197; W. B. Pratt shot 196, and J.
W. Young made 193.
In the match against the field,
which occurred on March 1, the
score of 982 wfts repeated. H. A.
Rowland and W. B. Pratt headed
the list each with 199; Chesholm
followed with 197; Van Hulstyn
made 195, and F. Smith shot 192.
The scores made against St.
Thomas on March 3 were not as
good as these, but since that college is now at the bottom of the
league, it is practically certain that
Hopkins, making the score 974,
won by a large margin. The results of the match with Lehigh,
held on March 1o, are still unknown.
The announcement was made
last week that each of the members
of the Johns Hopkins University
Rifle Club will be able to obtain a
Krag carbine, which cost the United States Government $20, for
$2.5o, to use in the outdoor practice. The Club offers this as an
added inducement to prospective
members, as no one can obtain one
of these rifles except through the
National Rifle Association.

All arrangements for the transportation of the library from McCoy Hall to Homewood have been
made. Although sonic of the books
will be moved in the early part of
the spring, the general moving will
not begin until the first of June and
will be completed before the opening of the summer session.
All the books that are needed for
the work in the summer school,
which is to be held in McCoy Hall,
will be placed in the reading-room
after the others have been removed,
and left there for the use of the
students until the session is over.
Then they also will be placed in the
library in the new Academic Building.
The question of shelving the
books at Homewood has not been
definitely settled, but eventually the
new library will bz entirely fitted
out w:th steel cases. The books
belonging to the biological laboratory will be placed in the basement
of the Academic Building in such
cases next year, while the geological and chemical libraries will be
temporar.ly installed in the big cases
which now stand in the present
reading-room. The shelving in the
reading-room is to be placed in the
offices of the members of the
faculty.
The general plan of the removal
of the library is for boxes just as
long as the shelves in the present
reading-room to be constructed,
and for the entire shelves of books
to be conveyed to Homewood intact. This will avoid all confusion,
and will be a great help in replacing the books on the shelves in the
new library.

May the Lord Have Mercy!

AT OTHER COLLEGES

An exchange tells of a justice of
the peace who was called upon to
perform a marriage ceremony. It
was his first attempt and he was at
a loss how to_proceed, but he arose
to the occasion. He commanded
the happy couple to stand up and
be sworn, as follows:
"Do you solemnly swear that you
will obey the Constitution of the
United States and the great State
of Indiana, and perform the duties
of your office, so help you God?"
The pair nodded assent and the
justice continued: "Then by the
power invested in me by the strong
arm of the law I pronounce you
man and wife, now, henceforth, and
forever, and you will stand committed until the fines and costs are
paid, and may the Lord have mercy
on your souls."—Ex.

Another Favors Recognition.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LErrER:

Dear Sir—The more winning
teams Hopkins can produce, the
higher will be her standing in the
intercollegiate world.
The independent swimming team
has made an enviable record for
itself without the help of the Athletic Association and with no rewards, in the form of letters, awaiting it. If the team were only
recognized and an "H. A. A." or
an "H. S." were awarded to each
member, the swimmers' ranks
would be greatly increased, and
Hopkins, through a still more successful team than the Independents, would mount higher on the
athletic ladder.
In the spring Hopkins supports
a lacrosse, a baseball, a track and
a tennis team. In the winter only
track. Surely we could advantageously add swimming as another
winter sport. Even if the followers of basket-ball get this game
recognized as a winter sport, it
would still mean that the University
would be represented by far fewer
teams than are on the field in the
springtime.
The majority of Hopkins students favor the recognition of the
swimming team, and there seems
to be no valid reason for going
contrary to their wishes. Recognition should be awarded within
the year.
'18.
March II, 1916.

The series of interclass basketball games is now at an end. The
fight for first place has been a
hotly-contested one. The freshman
team showed decided improvement
as the series progressed, but the
juniors displayed real championship form from the very start, with
the exception of one game with the
sophomores. The sophomores did
not have a good start, and, although
they defeated the juniors in one
game, they were not able to stand
the pace. The seniors shared the
same misfortune. The victorious
junior team will receive some sort
of a trophy and the individual players who participated in most of the
games will also receive medals.
These interclass games have
aroused a great deal of interest
among the student body, and every
contest has been attended by a
large crowd. It would seem,
from these indications, that basketball at Hopkins has a fair chance
of beconiing a recognized sport. A
strong team could be chosen from
among the league teams and there
are quite a few graduate and medical students who could be counted
upon.
Mr. Theodore E. Kistler, who
has done most of the work in connection with the formation of the
league, is highly in favor of this
plan. He said that he was very
much pleased with the sportsmanlike way in which all the games
were conducted and the enthusiastic
manner in which the student body
turned out to see them. He also
intimated that if the teams should
so desire it, outdoor goals at Homewood would be erected.
"These recent games," he said,
"are the first of their kind that have
ever been played in the Hopkins
gymnasium, and it certainly gives
me a great deal of satisfaction to
see how successful they have been
in every particular." Mr. Kistler
arranged the schedule of the series
and was referee at every game.
